recipes.name: Chilli Crab
ingredients: 1.2 kg Live Mud Crab (or Dungeness/Blue Crab), cleaned and cracked
1 tbsp Cornstarch mixed with 2 tbsp water (slurry)
instructions: Prepare the Crab: Clean the crab thoroughly, reserving the top shell. Crack the claws and body into pieces to allow the sauce to penetrate. Set aside.
Sauté Aromatics: Heat the oil in a large wok over medium-high heat. Add the chillies, garlic, and ginger, and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until fragrant.
Build the Sauce: Stir in the tomato ketchup, chilli sauce, fermented soybean paste, chicken stock, sugar, and salt. Bring the mixture to a rapid boil.

Cook the Crab: Add the crab pieces to the wok, including the reserved top shell. Stir well to coat the crab with the sauce. Cover the wok and simmer for 10-12 minutes, or until the crab is cooked through and the shells turn bright red.
Thicken the Sauce: Uncover the wok. Pour in the cornstarch slurry and stir continuously for about 30 seconds until the sauce thickens. Reduce the heat.

Finish with Egg: Pour the beaten egg into the simmering sauce in a slow, continuous stream while stirring quickly. This creates ribbons of cooked egg that give the sauce its characteristic velvety texture. Season to taste and serve immediately, garnished with fresh coriander.

recipes.name: Hainanese Chicken Rice
ingredients: 3 cups Jasmine Rice, rinsed and drained
4 tbsp Rendered chicken fat (from the chicken)
instructions: Poach the Chicken: Rub the chicken inside and out with salt. Stuff the cavity with half the ginger slices and spring onions. Place the chicken in a large pot and cover with water. Add 2 tsp salt and the knotted pandan leaves. Bring to a boil, then immediately reduce heat to a gentle simmer. Cook for 40-50 minutes, ensuring the water does not boil vigorously. Skim off impurities.

Ice Bath: Once cooked (juices run clear when pierced), immediately plunge the chicken into a large bowl of iced water for 10 minutes. This stops the cooking and gives the skin a gelatinous texture. Remove, hang to drain, and rub the skin with sesame oil. Reserve the stock.

Render Fat & Sauté Aromatics: Cut chicken fat deposits from the skin and place in a pan over low heat to render the fat (about 15-20 mins). Remove the crispy bits. Sauté the remaining ginger and minced garlic in 4 tbsp of the rendered chicken fat until fragrant (about 2 mins).

Cook the Rice: Add the rinsed rice to the pan and stir-fry in the fat/aromatics for 1 minute. Transfer the rice, 3 cups of hot chicken stock, and a new knotted pandan leaf bundle to a rice cooker. Cook as usual.

Serve: Chop the chicken into serving pieces. Serve immediately over the fragrant chicken rice, drizzled with light soy sauce and accompanied by fresh sliced cucumber, and the essential chilli and ginger sauces (prepared separately).

recipes.name: Laksa (Katong Style)
ingredients: 4 tbsp Dried Shrimp, soaked and drained
10 Dried Red Chillies, soaked and drained
2 stalks Lemongrass, white part only, bruised
instructions: Make the Paste: Blend all Laksa Paste ingredients in a food processor with a little water until smooth. Toast the belacan wrapped in foil beforehand.

Cook the Paste: Heat oil in a large pot or wok. Add the laksa paste and fry over medium heat for 5-7 minutes, stirring constantly until very fragrant and the oil separates (chili oil forms on the surface).

Prepare the Broth: Pour in the prawn or chicken stock and coconut milk. Bring to a gentle simmer, stirring well to incorporate the paste. Add the sliced fish cakes and tofu puffs. Simmer for 10 minutes to allow the flavors to develop.
Cook Protein: Add the peeled prawns to the simmering broth and cook for 2-3 minutes until they turn pink and opaque. Season the broth with salt, sugar, and fish sauce to taste.

Assemble: Briefly blanch the rice vermicelli and bean sprouts in hot water. Drain and divide them among serving bowls. Ladle the hot laksa broth, prawns, fish cake, and tofu puffs over the noodles. Garnish with a sprig of Laksa Leaves (Vietnamese Coriander) and serve immediately with a spoonful of sambal chilli on the side.

recipes.name: Char Kway Teow
ingredients: 1/2 cup Garlic Chives (Koo Chye), cut into 2-inch lengths
2 tbsp Sweet Dark Soy Sauce (Kecap Manis)
instructions: Prep: Mix all Sauce Mix ingredients in a small bowl. Ensure all ingredients are prepped and within arm's reach. Separate the Kway Teow noodles gently if they are clumped.

Sear Aromatics and Meat: Heat 2 tbsp of oil/lard in a wok over very high heat until smoking. Add garlic, Lap Cheong, and prawns/fish cake. Stir-fry rapidly for 1 minute until the prawns just turn pink.

Add Noodles and Sauce: Add the Kway Teow and yellow noodles (if using). Pour the sauce mix over the noodles and stir-fry using a tossing motion to coat everything evenly and quickly. The high heat is critical to achieve 'Wok Hei' (smoky flavor).
Push Aside: Create a well in the center of the wok by pushing the noodles to the sides. Add the remaining 2 tbsp of oil/lard to the well.

Add Egg and Finish: Crack the egg into the well and scramble it briefly. Once partially set, immediately toss it vigorously with the noodles to coat. Add the cockles (if using), bean sprouts, and chives. Stir-fry for a final 30 seconds. Do not overcook the vegetables—they should remain crisp.
Serve: Serve immediately on a plate while the noodles are still piping hot and smoky.

recipes.name: Bak Kut Teh (Teochew Style)
ingredients: 1 kg Meaty Pork Ribs (separated into individual ribs)
1 Whole head of Garlic, unpeeled and lightly bruised
2 tbsp Whole White Peppercorns, lightly crushed
1 tsp Whole Black Peppercorns, lightly crushed
Dark Soy Sauce with cut red chillies
instructions: Prepare Pork: Blanch the pork ribs in boiling water for 5 minutes. Drain the water and rinse the ribs thoroughly to remove any impurities and scum. Set aside.
Toast Peppercorns: Toast the crushed white and black peppercorns in a dry pan over medium heat for 1-2 minutes until fragrant. Place them in a spice bag or use a strainer/infuser for easy removal.
Simmer the Soup: In a large, clean pot, bring 2 litres of fresh water to a boil. Add the blanched pork ribs, the bag of toasted peppercorns, and 1 tbsp of salt.
Braise: Reduce the heat to a gentle simmer. Cover the pot and cook for 1 hour.
Add Aromatics and Finish: After 1 hour, add the bruised whole garlic head. Continue to simmer for another 30 minutes, or until the pork ribs are very tender. The soup should be clear and peppery.

Season and Serve: Remove the spice bag/strainer. Season the soup with 2 tsp of light soy sauce and more salt/pepper to taste. Serve piping hot with rice, a dipping sauce of dark soy sauce and sliced chilli padi, and pieces of You Tiao (Chinese fried dough sticks) for dipping.

recipes.name: Popiah (Fresh Spring Roll)
ingredients: 1/2 cup Pork belly or Chicken breast, shredded (optional)
instructions: Cook the Filling: Heat oil in a wok. Sauté minced garlic and chopped dried shrimp (and meat, if using) until fragrant (2 mins). Add the shredded jicama and carrots.

Braise the Vegetables: Stir-fry for a few minutes. Add water/stock, soy sauce, Tau Cheo, and sugar. Cover and simmer gently for 45-60 minutes, or until the jicama is very soft and translucent. The liquid should mostly be absorbed. Drain any excess liquid and cool the filling completely.
Prepare Condiments: Prepare the hard-boiled eggs, wash the lettuce and bean sprouts, and crush the peanuts. Arrange all ingredients assembly-line style.

Assemble the Popiah: Lay a popiah skin flat. Spread a thin layer of sweet dark sauce and chili paste (if using). Place a lettuce leaf on the skin, then a small amount of bean sprouts, egg, and crushed peanuts.

Roll: Scoop 2-3 spoonfuls of the cooled jicama filling onto the center. Fold the sides of the skin inwards, then roll up tightly from the bottom edge, like a burrito. Cut into two or three pieces and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Nasi Lemak
ingredients: 1 cup Dried Anchovies (Ikan Bilis), fried crisp
1 cup Sambal chili paste (pre-made or homemade)
instructions: Cook the Rice: Combine the rinsed rice, coconut milk, water, salt, knotted pandan leaves, and bruised lemongrass in a rice cooker. Cook on the regular rice setting. Once cooked, let it steam for 10 minutes, then fluff with a fork.
Prepare the Toppings: Fry the dried anchovies (Ikan Bilis) in hot oil until golden and crispy. Fry the peanuts until crunchy. Set aside.

Cook the Sambal: In a pan, heat 2 tbsp of oil and sauté the sliced onion until soft. Add the sambal chili paste and cook over low heat for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add sugar, salt, and tamarind paste (if using) to balance the taste. Simmer for 5-10 minutes until the oil separates (chili paste darkens).
Mix Anchovies (Optional): For the classic sambal ikan bilis, stir half of the crispy fried anchovies into the cooked sambal. Keep the rest separate for crunchy garnish.

Assemble: Serve a portion of the fragrant coconut rice. Top with a generous scoop of the sambal, a hard-boiled egg or sliced omelette, slices of cool cucumber, the remaining crispy anchovies, and roasted peanuts. Serve warm.

recipes.name: Hokkien Mee (Stir-fried)
ingredients: 500ml Rich Prawn and Pork Stock (Prawn heads/shells simmered with pork bones/skin)
1/4 cup Garlic Chives, cut into 1-inch lengths
instructions: Make the Stock (Crucial Step): Simmer prawn heads/shells (and pork bones/skin if using) in 5 cups of water for at least 30 minutes to make a rich, flavorful stock. Strain and set aside.
Prep Noodles: Blanch the yellow noodles briefly in boiling water to remove the alkaline smell, then drain. Set the Bee Hoon aside. Prep all other ingredients.
Stir-Fry Base: Heat the lard/oil in a wok over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and sauté until fragrant. Add the sliced pork belly (if using) and cook until browned, then push to the side.
Add Seafood: Add the prawns and squid. Stir-fry for 1 minute until partially cooked. Push to the side.
Braise Noodles: Add the noodles to the wok. Ladle about 1 cup of the rich stock over the noodles, stirring constantly. Let the noodles absorb the stock and soften. Add the fish sauce.

Add Egg and Finish: Push the noodles to the side, add a little more oil to the empty space, and pour in the beaten egg. Scramble quickly until half-cooked, then toss with the noodles. Add the bean sprouts and chives, and toss for a final 30 seconds. Add more stock for a saucier texture if desired.
Serve: Serve immediately with a dollop of sambal chili and a squeeze of calamansi lime juice to cut the richness.

recipes.name: Satay
ingredients: 600g Chicken, Beef, or Mutton, cut into thin strips
2 stalks Lemongrass, white part only, sliced
instructions: Marinate the Meat: Blend all marinade ingredients until a smooth paste forms. Toss the meat strips with the marinade and refrigerate for a minimum of 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Skewer: Thread the marinated meat strips onto the soaked bamboo skewers, ensuring the meat is tightly packed and flat.
Prepare for Grill: Preheat the grill to medium-high heat. Traditionally, satay is cooked over charcoal, fanned continuously.

Grill: Place the skewers on the hot grill. Cook for 3-5 minutes per side, turning frequently and basting lightly with residual marinade or oil to keep the meat moist. Cook until the meat is fully cooked through and slightly charred on the edges.
Serve: Serve immediately, arranged on a platter with generous portions of Satay Peanut Sauce on the side, and a simple salad of sliced cucumbers and red onions for a palate cleanser.

recipes.name: Gado Gado
ingredients: 1 cup Roasted Peanuts, ground into a paste
2 tbsp Tamarind Paste, mixed with 1/4 cup hot water
instructions: Prepare Vegetables: Blanch the green beans, cabbage, and bean sprouts until crisp-tender. Steam or boil the potatoes until cooked, then cube. Set all vegetables aside.
Prepare Tofu/Tempeh: Fry the tofu and tempeh until golden brown and crispy. Set aside.

Make the Dressing: In a food processor, blend the ground peanuts, coconut milk, tamarind liquid, palm sugar, salt, garlic, and chillies (if using) until smooth and creamy. Adjust the consistency with a little water or more coconut milk if too thick. The sauce should be pourable.
Warm the Dressing (Optional): Gently heat the sauce in a saucepan over low heat for 5 minutes, stirring until the oil separates slightly and it becomes very fragrant. Keep warm.
Assemble: Arrange all the prepared vegetables, fried tofu, fried tempeh, and hard-boiled egg halves on a large platter or individual plates.
Serve: Spoon the warm (or room temperature) peanut dressing generously over the entire platter. Garnish with fried shallots (optional) and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Kaya Toast with Soft-Boiled Eggs
ingredients: 4 slices Thin White Bread (traditionally Hainanese Toast)
4 tsp Butter, chilled and sliced thin
instructions: Toast the Bread: Slice the bread thinly. Toast the bread until it is crisp and golden brown (a charcoal grill or toaster is ideal, but a pan works too).

Assemble the Toast: Immediately slice the toast in half. While the bread is still hot, spread a generous layer of Kaya on one slice. Place 2-3 slices of chilled, hard butter on top of the Kaya. Place the second slice of toast on top to form a sandwich. The heat from the toast will gently melt the butter.

Boil the Eggs: Bring a small pot of water to a rolling boil. Remove the pot from the heat and gently lower the room-temperature eggs into the hot water. Cover the pot and let the eggs sit in the hot water for exactly 7 minutes for soft-boiled perfection.

Serve: Remove the eggs from the water and immediately crack them into a small bowl. The whites should be just set and the yolks runny. Season the eggs generously with light soy sauce and a dash of ground white pepper. Serve the Kaya Toast alongside the eggs.

recipes.name: Mee Goreng (Indian Style)
ingredients: 1 tbsp Chilli Sauce (or more for heat)
instructions: Prep: Blanch the yellow noodles briefly in hot water, then drain and set aside. Combine all Sauce Mix ingredients in a small bowl.
Stir-Fry Meat & Aromatics: Heat oil in a wok over high heat. Add garlic and onion and stir-fry until fragrant. Add the sliced chicken/seafood and stir-fry until almost cooked.
Add Vegetables: Add the shredded cabbage and tomato wedges. Stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until the cabbage softens slightly.
Add Noodles and Sauce: Add the prepared noodles and pour the entire Sauce Mix over them. Toss vigorously and continuously to coat the noodles and ingredients evenly. Cook for 2 minutes.

Finish with Egg: Push the noodles to the side of the wok. Add a little more oil and pour in the beaten eggs. Scramble the eggs quickly, then toss to mix them into the noodles. Add the bean sprouts and stir-fry for a final 30 seconds.
Serve: Serve immediately while hot. Garnish with a squeeze of lime juice if desired.

recipes.name: Roti Prata
ingredients: 3 tbsp Ghee or Oil, plus extra for resting
instructions: Make the Dough: In a large bowl, mix flour, water, egg, salt, and sugar to form a soft, slightly sticky dough. Knead for 5-7 minutes until smooth. Gradually incorporate 1 tbsp of ghee/oil while kneading.

Rest the Dough (Crucial Step): Divide the dough into 8 equal balls (80g each). Brush each ball generously with oil/ghee and place in a tray. Cover tightly with plastic wrap and let it rest at room temperature for at least 3 hours (or overnight in the fridge). This allows the gluten to relax.

Stretch the Dough: Lightly oil a clean, flat surface. Take one dough ball and flatten it into a disc. Using your palms and fingers (or by slapping and swinging, traditionally), stretch the dough outward until it is paper-thin and translucent (it should be about 18-20 inches wide).
Fold: Fold the edges of the thin dough inwards to form a square or a round shape, incorporating air for layers. *Alternatively, crumple it inward to form a round 'spiral'.*

Cook: Heat a flat pan or griddle over medium heat. Place the folded prata onto the dry pan. Cook for 2-3 minutes on each side until golden brown and flaky, turning frequently. Press down lightly with a spatula to cook thoroughly.

Fluff and Serve: Remove the prata from the pan and immediately scrunch the edges lightly with both hands to 'fluff' the layers. Serve immediately with a bowl of your favorite curry (fish or mutton is traditional).

recipes.name: Sambal Stingray
ingredients: 800g Stingray (skate) wing, trimmed and patted dry
15 Dried Red Chillies, soaked and drained
2 tbsp Tamarind Paste, mixed with 1/4 cup water
instructions: Prepare the Fish: Rub the stingray with salt and lime juice. Set aside.

Make the Sambal: Blend all Sambal Paste ingredients (chillies, shallots, garlic, ginger, galangal, toasted belacan) with a little oil until smooth. Strain the tamarind paste liquid and add it to the sambal, along with sugar.

Cook the Sambal: Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan and sauté the sambal paste over medium-low heat for 10-15 minutes, stirring constantly until very fragrant and the oil separates (chili oil forms on the surface). Set aside.
Prep for Grilling: Preheat the grill to medium-high heat. Lay a piece of banana leaf (or foil) on the grill rack. Place the stingray on the leaf.
Apply Sambal: Spread a generous, thick layer of the cooked sambal paste evenly over the top of the stingray. Garnish with sliced fresh shallots.
Grill: Grill the stingray on the banana leaf for 15-20 minutes, or until the fish is flaky and cooked through. The exact time depends on the thickness of the fish. Check the center for doneness.
Serve: Serve immediately, still on the banana leaf/foil, with a dipping sauce of *Cincalok* (fermented shrimp) or a simple blend of soy sauce and cut red chilli padi.

recipes.name: Kway Chap
ingredients: 3 tbsp Rock Sugar or Palm Sugar
1 tsp Cinnamon stick and star anise
1 whole head of Garlic, lightly crushed
instructions: Braise the Meat: Bring the water, dark and light soy sauces, sugar, five-spice powder, cinnamon, star anise, and crushed garlic to a boil. Add the blanched and cleaned pork belly and intestines. Reduce the heat and simmer for 1.5 to 2 hours, or until the pork belly is tender but still holds its shape. Add the tofu puffs (tau pok) and hard-boiled eggs in the last 15 minutes.

Prep the Kway (Rice Sheets): Bring a separate pot of water to a boil. Blanch the fresh Kway (rice sheets) in boiling water for 30 seconds to 1 minute until soft. Drain immediately and place them in individual serving bowls.

Prepare the Broth: Ladle about 1-2 cups of the braising liquid (the soy-sauce gravy) from the meat into a separate saucepan. Skim off excess oil. Dilute the gravy with a little plain water if it's too intense, and keep it warm. This will be the broth for the Kway.

Assemble and Serve: Slice the braised pork belly and intestines into bite-sized pieces. Arrange the sliced meat, intestines, tau pok, and egg halves over the blanched Kway in the serving bowls. Pour the warm, savory broth (braising liquid) over the Kway and ingredients. Serve immediately with a dipping sauce of chilli vinegar.

recipes.name: Bak Chor Mee (Minced Meat Noodles)
ingredients: 2 servings Fresh Mee Pok (Flat egg noodles) or Mee Kia (Thin egg noodles)
2 Dried Shiitake Mushrooms, soaked and sliced
instructions: Cook the Minced Meat: In a pan, sauté the minced pork and sliced mushrooms in 1 tbsp of oil/lard until cooked. Season lightly with soy sauce and set aside. (Some recipes braise the minced meat with dark soy sauce until flavorful.)
Prepare the Sauce: In the bottom of a serving bowl, mix the chilli paste, vinegar, soy sauce, fish sauce, and a generous amount of pork lard/oil. This forms the powerful, pungent base of the dish.

Cook Noodles and Ingredients: Blanch the noodles, sliced pork, fish balls, and vegetables in boiling water in separate stages (or one after another). The noodles should be cooked al dente (about 1-2 minutes).
Toss the Noodles: Drain the cooked noodles completely and immediately transfer them to the serving bowl containing the sauce mixture. Toss vigorously until the noodles are thoroughly coated.

Assemble and Serve: Top the noodles with the cooked minced pork and sliced mushrooms. Arrange the sliced pork, fish balls, and blanched greens on top. Garnish heavily with crispy fried shallots and serve immediately with a side bowl of the hot, clear noodle water/broth.

recipes.name: Ayam Buah Keluak
ingredients: 10-12 Buah Keluak (Black Nuts), scrubbed clean and soaked for 3-7 days (changing water daily)
5 pieces Assam Gelugor (Dried Sour Tamarind Slices)
instructions: Prepare Buah Keluak: Soak the nuts for several days (changing water daily) to detoxify. Crack open the top of the nuts and scoop out the black pulp. Mix the pulp with a little salt and set aside. (Some recipes stuff the pulp back into the nuts before cooking.)
Make the Rempah: Blend all Rempah ingredients (chillies, shallots, garlic, galangal, turmeric, belacan, lemongrass) until a smooth paste is formed.
Sauté Rempah: Heat oil in a pot and fry the rempah over medium-low heat for 15-20 minutes, stirring until very fragrant and the oil separates.
Braise the Chicken: Add the chicken pieces to the pot and stir to coat them thoroughly with the rempah. Cook until the chicken is browned.

Add Liquids and Nuts: Add the tamarind juice and chicken stock, ensuring the chicken is mostly covered. Add the prepared *Buah Keluak* nuts and the extra black pulp mixture. Add the Assam Gelugor slices.

Simmer: Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to a gentle simmer. Cover and braise for 1 to 1.5 hours, or until the chicken is very tender and the sauce is thick and oil has risen to the top. Serve hot with white rice, using a small spoon to scoop out the nutty pulp from inside the nuts.

recipes.name: Assam Laksa
ingredients: 400g Thick Rice Vermicelli or thick rice noodles
1.5 kg Whole Mackerel or Sardines (or equivalent fish fillets)
5 pieces Assam Gelugor (Dried Sour Tamarind Slices)
Torch Ginger Flower (Bunga Kantan), sliced thin (essential)
instructions: Cook the Fish: Bring the water to a boil with the onion. Add the whole fish and simmer for 15-20 minutes until cooked. Remove the fish, flake the flesh, and return the bones to the broth to simmer for another 30 minutes. Strain the broth and set aside.
Make the Spice Base: Blend the paste ingredients (chillies, galangal, turmeric, lemongrass, belacan) until smooth.

Simmer the Broth: Bring the strained fish broth back to a simmer. Add the blended spice paste, the flaked fish, and the Assam Gelugor. Cook for 20 minutes to allow the flavors to marry. Season with salt and sugar to achieve a balance of sour, spicy, and savory.
Prepare Noodles and Garnish: Blanch the rice noodles until soft. Arrange the shredded cucumber, pineapple, onion, mint leaves, and torch ginger flower in individual bowls.
Assemble: Place a portion of noodles in a bowl. Ladle the hot, sour, fish-laden broth over the noodles. Top with the prepared garnish and serve with a dollop of sweet prawn paste (*Hae Ko*).

recipes.name: Carrot Cake (Chai Tow Kway)
ingredients: 500g Steamed Radish Cake (Chai Tow Kway), cut into small cubes
1 tbsp Preserved Radish (Chai Poh), rinsed and drained
1 tbsp Sweet Dark Soy Sauce (for 'Black' version only)
instructions: Prepare the Radish Cake: Ensure the steamed radish cake is cool and cut into 1-inch cubes. Rinse the preserved radish (*Chai Poh*) briefly to remove excess salt.

Fry the Cake: Heat the oil/lard in a wok over high heat. Add the chopped radish cake cubes and fry them until the edges are crispy and slightly caramelized (about 5-7 minutes). Push the cakes to the side.
Sauté Aromatics: Add a little more oil to the center of the wok. Add the chopped garlic and preserved radish (*Chai Poh*). Stir-fry quickly until fragrant (about 1 minute).

Combine and Season: Mix the fried cake, garlic, and *Chai Poh* together. Add the fish sauce and light soy sauce. If making the 'Black' version, add the sweet dark soy sauce now and toss until the cake is evenly coated in a dark glaze. (Add chilli paste now for the spicy version).
Add Egg: Pour the beaten eggs over the cake mixture. Let the egg set slightly before tossing gently to incorporate the egg, creating creamy clumps around the cake pieces.
Serve: Serve immediately, garnished with chopped spring onions.

recipes.name: Prawn Mee (Hae Mee)
ingredients: 400g Yellow Egg Noodles and/or Thick Bee Hoon (Rice Vermicelli)
200g Pork Ribs or Sliced Pork Belly (optional)
Kangkong (Water Spinach) or Bean Sprouts, blanched
instructions: Make the Prawn Oil: Heat 2 tbsp oil/lard in a large pot. Add the reserved prawn heads and shells. Fry over medium heat, pressing down on the heads, until they turn red and fragrant, releasing their oil (about 5-7 minutes). Remove the heads/shells and set aside.

Make the Broth: Add the 2 litres of water, crushed garlic, rock sugar, and the fried prawn heads/shells (optional: add pork bones/ribs) to the same pot. Bring to a boil, then simmer gently for 1 to 1.5 hours to create a rich, savory red broth. Strain the broth and discard the solids. Season the broth with salt.
Cook Noodles and Toppings: Blanch the noodles, sliced pork, prawns, and vegetables in boiling water in separate stages (or one after another). Drain and place them in individual serving bowls.

Assemble and Serve: Pour the piping hot prawn broth over the noodles and toppings. Garnish generously with crispy fried shallots, a halved hard-boiled egg, and (optional) a spoonful of chili powder/paste for heat. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Rojak (Fruit and Vegetable Salad)
ingredients: 2 pieces Tau Pok (Fried Tofu Puffs), cut into pieces
4 tbsp Thick, Sweet Prawn Paste (Hae Ko)
2 tbsp Tamarind Pulp, mixed with 1/4 cup hot water (strained)
1 tsp Sambal Chilli Paste (or more to taste)
instructions: Prepare Ingredients: Cut all the fruit and vegetables into bite-sized pieces. Blanch the bean sprouts and cut the fried tofu puffs. Crush the roasted peanuts.

Make the Dressing: In a large mortar and pestle or a mixing bowl, combine the thick prawn paste (*Hae Ko*), strained tamarind liquid, shaved palm sugar, sambal chilli, and water. Stir and pound until the palm sugar is fully dissolved and the sauce is smooth, sticky, and well-mixed.
Mix the Salad: Place all the cut fruit, vegetables, and tofu puffs into the mixing bowl/mortar.

Toss and Coat: Pour the prepared sticky black dressing over the fruits and vegetables. Toss everything vigorously (or pound lightly with the pestle) until all ingredients are evenly coated in the thick, pungent sauce.
Serve: Transfer the Rojak to a serving plate and garnish generously with the crushed peanuts. Serve immediately, as the sauce will make the crisp ingredients soggy over time.

recipes.name: Cendol
ingredients: 200g Palm Sugar (Gula Melaka), shaved or chopped
Canned or Fresh Red Beans (Azuki/Adzuki), optional
instructions: Make the Gula Melaka Syrup: Combine the shaved palm sugar, water, and knotted pandan leaves in a small saucepan. Heat over medium-low heat, stirring until the sugar is completely dissolved and the mixture thickens into a dark, fragrant syrup. Strain the syrup and allow it to cool completely.
Prepare the Coconut Milk: Mix the thick coconut milk with a pinch of salt. Do not boil. Chill the coconut milk until ready to use.
Assemble: Fill a serving bowl generously with finely shaved ice. (Using a blender or food processor to make shaved ice works if a machine is unavailable).
Layer the Ingredients: Pour a generous amount of the chilled coconut milk over the ice. Add a large scoop of the green *Cendol* rice flour jellies and, if desired, a scoop of sweet red beans.
Drizzle: Drizzle the cool, thick *Gula Melaka* syrup liberally over the top. Serve immediately, mixing well to enjoy the combination of sweet, salty, and icy flavors.

recipes.name: Fish Head Curry
ingredients: 1 large Fish Head (Snapper, Grouper, or Threadfin), cleaned
1 tbsp Chilli Powder (or more to taste)
Assorted Vegetables (e.g., Lady's Fingers/Okra, Tomato wedges, Eggplant pieces)
instructions: Prepare the Fish: Clean the fish head thoroughly and rub it with a little salt and turmeric powder. Set aside.
Sauté Aromatics: Heat oil in a large clay pot or deep pan. Add the sliced onion and curry leaves and sauté until the onion is soft and fragrant.

Bloom the Curry: Lower the heat. Mix the fish curry powder and chili powder with a little water to form a paste. Add the paste to the pot and fry for 5-7 minutes, stirring constantly until the oil separates (a process called 'tumis').
Add Liquids: Pour in the water/fish stock and the tamarind juice. Bring the mixture to a boil. Add the chopped vegetables (except tomatoes) and simmer for 5 minutes.
Cook the Fish: Place the fish head into the simmering gravy. Cover and cook for 10 minutes.

Finish the Curry: Pour in the coconut milk and add the tomato wedges. Simmer gently for another 5-10 minutes, ensuring the gravy doesn't boil vigorously after adding the coconut milk. Season with salt and a pinch of sugar to balance the sourness. The fish head should be cooked through. Serve immediately in the clay pot with steamed rice or *Roti Prata*.

recipes.name: Popiah (Deep Fried Spring Rolls)
ingredients: 16 sheets Spring Roll Wrappers (or Popiah skin)
1 kg Cooked Popiah Filling (Jicama, carrots, mushrooms, as prepared for fresh popiah)
50g Bean Thread Noodles (Glass Noodles), soaked and cut
instructions: Prepare the Filling: Ensure the Popiah filling (typically braised jicama, carrots, etc.) is fully cooked, drained of excess liquid, and completely cool. Adding warm or wet filling will result in a soggy spring roll.

Assemble the Rolls: Lay a spring roll wrapper flat with a corner pointing towards you. Place 2-3 spoonfuls of the cooled filling near the bottom corner. Fold the bottom corner up over the filling, then fold the left and right corners inward, creating an envelope shape.
Roll and Seal: Roll the wrapper tightly upwards toward the final corner. Brush the final corner edge with the beaten egg wash to seal the roll tightly. Repeat for all wrappers.
Deep Fry: Heat the vegetable oil in a deep pot or wok to $180^\circ	ext{C}$ ($350^\circ	ext{F}$). Carefully lower the spring rolls into the hot oil in batches, ensuring not to overcrowd the wok.
Finish: Fry for 4-6 minutes, turning occasionally, until the wrappers are crispy and uniformly golden brown. Remove the rolls and drain them immediately on a wire rack or paper towels.
Serve: Serve hot with a side of sweet chili sauce or plum sauce. Cut the rolls diagonally before serving to show the filling.

recipes.name: Ngo Hiang (Five-Spice Meat Rolls)
ingredients: 5-6 sheets Dried Bean Curd Skin (Fu Pi), soaked and cut
instructions: Prepare the Filling: In a large bowl, combine the ground pork, chopped water chestnuts, shredded carrots, minced shallots, soy sauce, sesame oil, rice wine, five-spice powder, salt, pepper, and the beaten egg. Mix well by hand until the mixture is sticky and well combined.
Prepare the Skin: Soak the dried bean curd skin in warm water for 5 minutes until pliable. Drain and pat dry. Cut the skin into large rectangles (approx. 10x15 cm) suitable for rolling.

Roll the Ngo Hiang: Place a portion of the meat mixture along one end of the bean curd skin rectangle. Fold the sides inward, then roll up tightly like a thick sausage. Use a bit of cornstarch slurry or water to seal the edge. Repeat until all meat is used.
Steam: Steam the rolls for 15-20 minutes until the meat filling is cooked through. Cool the rolls completely. (This step helps the rolls hold their shape when frying).

Deep Fry: Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or deep pan to $170^\circ	ext{C}$ ($340^\circ	ext{F}$). Fry the steamed rolls in batches for 5-7 minutes, turning frequently, until they are golden brown and crispy. Remove and drain.
Serve: Slice the rolls diagonally into thick pieces. Serve immediately with a side of sweet sauce or chilli sauce.

recipes.name: Curry Puff
ingredients: 300g Chicken Breast, cubed small (or boiled potato for veg)
300g Potato, cubed small and boiled until tender
instructions: Make the Filling: Sauté the diced onion in oil until soft. Add the chicken/meat and cook until browned. Stir in the curry powder and cook for 1 minute until fragrant. Add the diced, cooked potato, water/stock, salt, and sugar. Simmer for 5-7 minutes until the liquid reduces and the filling is thick and dry. Cool completely.

Make the Pastry: In a bowl, cut the cold butter/margarine into the flour and salt until it resembles coarse crumbs. Gradually add iced water to form a soft dough. Knead briefly, wrap, and chill for 30 minutes.
Assemble the Puffs: Roll out the chilled dough thinly. Use a round cutter (approx 10-12 cm diameter) to cut out circles. Place a spoonful of the cool filling slightly off-center on each circle.
Seal and Crimp: Fold the dough over the filling to form a semi-circle. Crimp the edges tightly using your fingers or a fork to seal (or use a classic spiral twist crimping technique).

Cook: Deep-fry the puffs in oil at $170^\circ	ext{C}$ ($340^\circ	ext{F}$) for 5-7 minutes until golden brown and flaky. Alternatively, bake at $180^\circ	ext{C}$ ($350^\circ	ext{F}$) for 20-25 minutes. Serve warm.

recipes.name: Tau Huay (Soya Beancurd)
ingredients: 200g White Sugar (or Brown/Gula Melaka for color)
instructions: Prepare the Syrups: Combine sugar, water, and pandan leaves in a saucepan. Bring to a boil, stirring until the sugar dissolves. Simmer briefly until slightly thick. Remove pandan leaves and cool the syrup completely.
Prepare the Setting Agent: Mix the gypsum powder and cornstarch in a large, heatproof serving bowl. Add 3 tbsp of water and stir until fully dissolved. Do not disturb the bowl afterward.

Heat Soy Milk: Heat the fresh soy milk in a pot over medium heat. Do not let it boil vigorously. Stir constantly to prevent skin formation. Bring it to just below boiling point ($85^\circ	ext{C}$ - $90^\circ	ext{C}$).

Pour and Set (Critical Step): Remove the soy milk from the heat. Pour the hot soy milk quickly but smoothly and in a single stream from a medium height into the bowl containing the setting agent mixture. **DO NOT STIR OR SHAKE** after pouring.
Allow to Set: Cover the bowl and let it sit undisturbed at room temperature for 45-60 minutes, or until the mixture sets into a smooth, silky custard. Chill if desired.
Serve: To serve, use a large, shallow spoon to scoop thin, delicate layers of the set beancurd into individual bowls. Ladle the cool sugar syrup over the top.

recipes.name: Mee Siam (Siamese Noodle)
ingredients: 3 tbsp Tamarind Paste, mixed with 1/2 cup water
1/2 cup Dried Shrimp, soaked and ground
10 Dried Red Chillies, soaked and drained
instructions: Prepare Bee Hoon: Soak the rice vermicelli in hot water for 10 minutes until soft. Drain and toss briefly with a spoonful of oil and light soy sauce to prevent sticking.
Make the Gravy Paste: Blend the spice paste ingredients (chillies, shallots, garlic, galangal) and ground dried shrimp until smooth.

Sauté and Simmer: Heat oil in a pot. Fry the blended paste and the Tau Cheo (soybean paste) for 5-7 minutes until very fragrant. Add the water/stock, strained tamarind juice, and palm sugar. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes until the gravy slightly thickens. Season with salt/fish sauce for a balance of sweet, sour, and spicy.
Final Fry (Optional): Some recipes briefly stir-fry the prepared bee hoon noodles with the gravy (a dry version). For the soup version, keep the gravy separate.

Assemble: Place the noodles in a serving bowl. Pour the hot gravy/broth over the noodles. Top with blanched bean sprouts, chives, halved hard-boiled eggs, and tau pok. Serve with a wedge of lime to squeeze over the dish.

recipes.name: Ice Kachang (Ais Kacang)
ingredients: 1/2 cup Sweet Corn Kernels (canned or cooked)
4 tbsp Gula Melaka Syrup (Palm Sugar Syrup)
4 tbsp Evaporated Milk or Condensed Milk (optional)
instructions: Prepare the Ice: Ensure you have finely shaved ice, ideally resembling snow. This is the foundation of the dessert.
Layer the Base: Place the cooked red beans, sweet corn, *Attap Chee* (palm seeds), and *Cendol* jellies (if using) into the bottom of individual serving bowls.
Mound the Ice: Scoop the finely shaved ice over the base ingredients, creating a high, dome-shaped mound (like a mountain).
Add Syrup: Drizzle the cool *Gula Melaka* syrup evenly over the ice dome, followed by the pink/red Rose Syrup. These should color the ice brightly.
Finish: Drizzle the evaporated milk (or condensed milk for extra sweetness) over the entire mound. Top with crushed peanuts (optional).
Serve: Serve immediately with a long spoon. The mix of icy coolness, sugary syrup, and chewy toppings is enjoyed by mixing everything together.

recipes.name: Fishball Noodles (Teochew)
ingredients: 2 servings Fresh Yellow Noodles (Mee Pok, Mee Kia, or Kway Teow)
1/2 cup Kangkong (Water Spinach), or Chinese greens
instructions: Prepare Stock and Condiments: Ensure the fish stock is hot. Blanch the bean sprouts and greens and set aside. For the 'Dry' version, mix the oil/lard, soy sauce, fish sauce, and pepper in a large serving bowl. Add chili or vinegar if desired.

Cook Noodles and Protein: Blanch the noodles in boiling water until cooked al dente (1-2 minutes). Simultaneously, cook the fish balls and fish dumplings in the stock or boiling water until they float and are cooked through.
Serve (Dry Version): Drain the cooked noodles completely and immediately transfer them to the serving bowl containing the sauce mixture. Toss vigorously until fully coated.

Assemble (Dry and Soup): Top the noodles with the cooked fish balls, fish dumplings, and blanched vegetables. Serve the 'Dry' noodles with a side bowl of the hot fish stock containing a few fish balls and the greens. For the 'Soup' version, ladle the hot stock directly over the noodles and toppings.

recipes.name: Oyster Omelette (Orh Luak)
ingredients: 2 tbsp Tapioca Starch (or sweet potato starch)
1/2 tsp Salt and 1/2 tsp White Pepper
instructions: Prepare Batter: In a bowl, mix the tapioca starch, rice flour, and water until smooth. Season the beaten eggs with fish sauce, salt, and pepper.
Cook Oysters (Optional Pre-cook): Quickly blanch the oysters in hot water for 30 seconds and drain, or simply pat them dry. Season with salt and pepper.

Cook the Batter: Heat a large wok or flat pan over high heat with half the oil/lard. Pour the starch batter into the hot pan and spread it out. Cook for 2-3 minutes until the batter is slightly set and crispy on the bottom.
Add Egg and Oysters: Pour the seasoned beaten eggs over the set batter, distributing the egg evenly. Immediately scatter the fresh or pre-cooked oysters over the top. Cook for another 2 minutes.

Flip and Finish: Gently flip the omelette (in parts or whole) to cook the egg thoroughly. Add the remaining oil/lard to crisp up the edges. Just before serving, sprinkle generously with chopped spring onions/coriander.
Serve: Serve immediately while piping hot with a side of chili sauce mixed with a little vinegar.

recipes.name: Kueh Lapis Sagu (Nine Layer Steamed Cake)
ingredients: 1 tsp Red or Pink Food Coloring
instructions: Prepare the Batter: Dissolve the sugar and salt in the water over low heat. Add the knotted pandan leaves and heat until the sugar dissolves. Let it cool completely. Mix the tapioca flour and rice flour in a large bowl. Gradually add the cool sugar syrup and coconut milk to the flour mixture, whisking until a smooth, thin batter forms. Strain the batter.

Divide the Batter: Divide the batter into two main portions. Keep one portion white/natural. Color the second portion with a few drops of red/pink food coloring (or divide it further for multiple colors).

Layer 1 (Crucial): Lightly grease an 8-inch square pan and line with parchment paper. Pour the first layer (about 60-80ml) of colored batter into the pan. Steam over medium heat for 5-7 minutes until the layer is set.

Layer and Repeat: Pour the next layer of a contrasting color (e.g., white batter) over the first set layer. Steam again for 5-7 minutes. Continue this process, alternating colors, until all 9 layers are completed. Ensure the base layers are set before adding the next one.
Final Steam: Steam the final layer for a full 15-20 minutes to ensure the entire cake is cooked through.

Cool and Serve: Remove the cake from the steamer and let it cool completely to room temperature before attempting to cut (this takes 4-6 hours). Slice the cake into rectangular pieces and serve. The layers should peel apart easily.

recipes.name: Sotong Bakar (Grilled Squid)
ingredients: 600g Large Squid (Sotong), cleaned and scored (body left whole)
instructions: Prepare the Squid: Clean the squid thoroughly. Score the body lightly in a diamond pattern to prevent curling and to help the marinade penetrate. Pat dry and toss with salt and lime juice.
Make the Marinade: In a small bowl, whisk together the *Kecap Manis*, sambal chili paste, oil, sugar, and minced garlic until smooth.

Marinate and Prep for Grill: Brush the squid generously, inside and out, with the marinade. Let it sit for 15-20 minutes (no longer, as acid can toughen the squid). Preheat the grill to medium-high heat.
Grill: Place the marinated squid directly on the hot grill or on a grilling mat. Grill for 3-4 minutes per side. Baste frequently with the remaining marinade/paste during grilling.
Finish: The squid is done when it is opaque, firm, and slightly charred at the edges. Be careful not to overcook, or it will become rubbery (it should take less than 8 minutes total).
Serve: Slice the grilled squid into rings or diagonal pieces. Serve immediately with a side of lime wedges and extra sambal chili.

recipes.name: Sayur Lodeh (Vegetables in Coconut Gravy)
instructions: Make the Spice Paste: Blend all spice paste ingredients (shallots, garlic, turmeric, chillies, and soaked dried shrimp if using) until smooth.
Sauté Aromatics: Heat 2 tbsp of oil in a pot. Fry the blended spice paste, the bruised galangal, and bruised lemongrass for 5-7 minutes until very fragrant. This is the *tumis* step.
Simmer the Gravy: Pour in the thin coconut milk and water/stock. Bring the mixture to a boil. Reduce the heat and add the hardier vegetables first (jicama, eggplant, beans). Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add remaining ingredients: Add the cabbage and tofu puffs (*Tau Pok*). Simmer for another 5 minutes, until the vegetables are tender-crisp.

Finish with Thick Coconut Milk: Pour in the thick coconut milk. Stir gently and heat until the gravy is just simmering (do not boil vigorously after adding the thick milk). Season generously with salt and a pinch of sugar to taste. Serve hot with rice or *Lontong* (compressed rice cakes).

recipes.name: Sambal Kangkong (Water Spinach)
ingredients: 500g Kangkong (Water Spinach), trimmed and cut into 2-inch lengths
4 tbsp Sambal Belacan (Premade or homemade chili paste with shrimp paste)
instructions: Prepare the Kangkong: Wash the water spinach thoroughly and drain well. Separate the stems from the leaves; the stems may take slightly longer to cook.
Heat the Wok: Heat the oil in a wok over very high heat until smoking. Add the minced garlic and sliced onion and stir-fry for 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add Sambal: Add the *Sambal Belacan* paste, sugar, and salt. Stir-fry rapidly for 1 minute until the paste is fragrant and darkens slightly. (Add water if the paste is too dry).

Add Kangkong: Immediately add the kangkong stems first, stir-fry for 30 seconds, then add the leaves. Stir-fry the vegetables rapidly for only 1-2 minutes until they are slightly wilted but still crunchy and bright green.
Season and Serve: Adjust seasoning if necessary (the sambal is often salty). Serve immediately while the kangkong is still hot and crisp.

recipes.name: Chwee Kueh (Steamed Rice Cake)
ingredients: 1 cup Preserved Salted Radish (Chai Poh), rinsed and finely chopped
1/2 cup Dried Shrimp, soaked and minced (optional)
1 tbsp Dark Sweet Soy Sauce (Kecap Manis)
instructions: Make the Cakes: In a saucepan, whisk the rice flour, cornstarch, water, and salt until smooth. Cook over low heat, stirring continuously until the mixture thickens slightly (about 5-7 minutes).

Steam the Cakes: Grease small, shallow metal bowls or teacups. Pour the thickened batter into the cups (about 3/4 full). Steam over high heat for 15-20 minutes, until a smooth, slightly concave indentation forms in the center. Cool completely before unmolding.

Make the Topping: Heat the oil/lard in a wok. Add the minced garlic and dried shrimp (if using) and stir-fry until fragrant. Add the finely chopped *Chai Poh*. Stir-fry over low heat for 10-15 minutes until the radish is crispy and dark brown.
Season Topping: Stir in the dark sweet soy sauce and sugar. Taste and adjust seasoning (it should be savory-sweet). Let the topping cool slightly.
Serve: Arrange the cooled, unmolded rice cakes on a plate. Spoon a generous amount of the warm, savory-sweet *Chai Poh* topping over the cakes. Serve with chili sauce on the side.

recipes.name: Roti Jala with Curry
ingredients: Chicken Curry or Vegetable Curry (e.g., Sayur Lodeh)
instructions: Make the Batter: Whisk together the flour, coconut milk, egg, salt, and turmeric powder until a very smooth, thin batter forms. It should be easily pourable. Strain the batter to ensure no lumps remain.
Prepare the Dispenser: Pour the batter into a *Roti Jala* dispenser (a cup with three to five small holes) or a funnel with a small opening.

Cook the Crepes: Lightly grease a non-stick pan over medium heat. Hold the dispenser/funnel about 6-8 inches above the pan and quickly pour the batter in a circular, netting motion to create a lace-like pattern (a 'net').

Fold: Cook for 1-2 minutes until the net crepe is set and the edges are dry (it should not brown much). Carefully remove the crepe and fold it into quarters or roll it up like a cigarette. Repeat until all batter is used.
Serve: Serve the warm *Roti Jala* immediately alongside a generous bowl of rich, mildly spiced chicken or vegetable curry.

recipes.name: Katong Prawn Noodles (Dry)
ingredients: 2 servings Yellow Noodles and/or Bee Hoon (Rice Vermicelli)
1 tbsp Sweet Dark Soy Sauce (Kecap Manis)
Small bowl of Prawn Stock (prepared separately, see Prawn Mee recipe)
instructions: Prepare the Sauce: In the bottom of a large serving bowl, mix the oil/lard, light soy sauce, sweet dark soy sauce, chilli paste, vinegar (if using), and sugar. Stir well to form the base coating.
Cook Noodles and Toppings: Blanch the noodles and vegetables (bean sprouts, kangkong) in boiling water until cooked, then drain well. Quickly blanch the peeled prawns until cooked (about 1 minute).

Toss: Transfer the hot, well-drained noodles and vegetables immediately to the serving bowl containing the sauce mixture. Toss vigorously until the noodles are thoroughly coated in the dark, chili sauce.

Assemble and Serve: Place the tossed noodles on a plate. Arrange the cooked prawns and, optionally, sliced fish cake on top. Serve immediately with a side bowl of rich, hot prawn broth (stock) for dipping and sipping.

recipes.name: Kuih Kosui
ingredients: 1 tsp Lye Water (Air Abu) (optional, but gives chewy texture)
2 cups Freshly Grated Coconut (steamed for 10 mins with a pinch of salt)
instructions: Make the Syrup: Combine the shaved Gula Melaka and water in a saucepan. Heat until the sugar dissolves completely. Strain the syrup to remove impurities. Let it cool slightly.

Make the Batter: In a large bowl, mix the rice flour and tapioca flour. Add the cooled Gula Melaka syrup, thick coconut milk, lye water (if using), and salt. Whisk until the batter is smooth and lump-free.

Steam the Cake: Pour the batter into small, individual oiled teacups or silicone molds, or a single 8-inch square pan. Steam over high heat for 20-30 minutes until the kuih is translucent and firm to the touch.
Cool and Unmold: Remove the kuih from the steamer and let it cool completely. They must be cold before unmolding. If using a large pan, cut them into small diamonds or squares.
Serve: Roll or coat the cool, sticky, brown kuih generously in the steamed, salted grated coconut. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Duck Porridge (Orh Luak)
ingredients: 3 cups Water (or use some duck braising liquid)
Fried Shallots, Spring Onion, White Pepper
instructions: Braise the Duck: Blanch the duck pieces in boiling water for 5 minutes and rinse. Place the duck in a large pot. Add dark and light soy sauces, ginger, star anise, cinnamon stick, and water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 1.5 to 2 hours until the duck is very tender. Reserve the braising liquid (broth).

Cook the Porridge: Rinse the white rice. In a separate pot, combine the rice and 3 cups of water (or use a mix of water and the duck braising liquid for flavor). Bring to a boil, then reduce to a very low simmer. Cook for 30-45 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the rice grains burst and form a smooth porridge (congee). Season with salt.

Assemble and Serve: Ladle the hot porridge into serving bowls. Place a generous amount of the braised duck pieces on top. Drizzle a little of the dark, savory duck braising liquid over the porridge and meat.
Garnish: Sprinkle generously with white pepper, chopped spring onions, and crispy fried shallots. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Curry Chicken
ingredients: 1 kg Chicken, cut into pieces (on the bone preferred)
instructions: Marinate Chicken: Toss the chicken pieces with 2 tbsp of the curry powder and salt. Set aside.
Sauté Aromatics: Heat oil in a large pot. Add the sliced onion, bruised lemongrass, and curry leaves. Sauté until the onion is soft and fragrant (3 mins).
Bloom the Curry: Reduce the heat to low. Add the remaining 2 tbsp of curry powder and fry for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly until fragrant (the *tumis* step).
Brown Chicken: Add the marinated chicken and stir-fry for 5 minutes until the pieces are lightly browned and coated in the paste.
Simmer the Curry: Add the cubed potatoes and water/stock. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 20 minutes, or until the potatoes are half-cooked.

Finish: Pour in the thick coconut milk. Add salt and sugar. Simmer gently (do not boil vigorously) for another 10-15 minutes, until the chicken is cooked through, the potatoes are tender, and the gravy has thickened slightly. Serve hot with rice, bread, or *Roti Prata*.

recipes.name: Mutton Soup (Sup Kambing)
ingredients: 1 kg Mutton or Lamb with bone (shoulder or leg), cubed
4 tbsp Mutton Soup Powder (or mixed whole spices: star anise, cinnamon, cardamom, cloves)
instructions: Prep the Mutton: Blanch the mutton in boiling water for 5 minutes, drain, and rinse thoroughly to remove impurities.
Sauté Aromatics: Heat ghee/oil in a large pot. Add the sliced onions and sauté until soft and caramelized. Add the minced garlic and pounded ginger and stir-fry until fragrant (3 mins).
Bloom Spices: Add the mutton soup powder (or whole spices) and fry for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.

Braise the Mutton: Add the blanched mutton pieces and stir to coat. Pour in the 3 litres of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to a gentle simmer. Cover and cook for 2 to 2.5 hours, or until the mutton is fork-tender.
Finish the Soup: Skim any excess fat off the surface. Season the soup with salt to taste. Stir in evaporated milk (if using) for a creamy, richer broth. Heat through gently.
Serve: Ladle the hot, spiced soup and tender mutton into bowls. Garnish heavily with chopped celery/spring onion and crispy fried shallots. Serve with sliced bread or rice.

recipes.name: Hokkien Popiah (Soup Version)
ingredients: 1 Litre Prawn or Chicken Stock (rich broth essential)
Fish Cake slices, Chives, Crispy Fried Shallots
instructions: Prepare Stock: Ensure a rich prawn or chicken stock is simmering hot (see Prawn Mee recipe for stock details).

Stir-Fry Base: Heat oil/lard in a wok. Add minced garlic and sauté until fragrant (30 seconds). Add the prawns and sliced pork/chicken (if using) and stir-fry until cooked. Push the ingredients to the side.
Cook Vegetables: Add the shredded cabbage and carrots to the wok and stir-fry briefly until slightly softened (2 mins). Add the stock and bring everything to a boil.
Add Noodles: Add the fresh yellow noodles (briefly blanched beforehand to remove alkalinity) to the simmering broth. Simmer for 3-5 minutes, allowing the noodles to absorb the broth and flavor.

Season and Serve: Stir in the light and dark soy sauces and salt. Taste and adjust seasoning. Ladle the hot soup and noodles into a bowl. Top with slices of fish cake, chives, and generous crispy fried shallots. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Kueh Dadar (Coconut Pancake Roll)
ingredients: 1 tsp Pandan Essence (or blend pandan leaves with milk)
instructions: Make the Filling: Combine the shaved Gula Melaka, water, and knotted pandan leaf in a pan. Heat until the sugar dissolves. Add the grated coconut and cook over low-medium heat, stirring continuously, until the liquid evaporates and the coconut is caramelized, sticky, and dry (15-20 minutes). Remove the pandan leaf and cool.
Make the Batter: Whisk the flour, egg, coconut milk, pandan essence (which colors it green), and salt until a smooth, thin crepe batter forms. Strain the batter.

Cook the Crepes: Lightly oil a non-stick pan over medium heat. Pour a thin layer of batter into the pan and swirl to cover the base, creating a thin green crepe. Cook for 1-2 minutes until the edges are dry and the surface is set. Remove from the pan.

Assemble the Rolls: Lay a green crepe flat. Place a spoonful of the cooled, sticky coconut filling (*Inti Kelapa*) near one edge. Fold the sides inward, then roll up tightly like a spring roll or cigar.
Serve: Serve the rolls at room temperature. The vibrant green exterior and rich brown filling make it a beautiful dessert.

recipes.name: Barbecued Stingray (Ikan Bakar)
ingredients: 800g Whole Fish or Fillets (e.g., Stingray, Snapper, or Kembong)
2 tbsp Tamarind Paste, mixed with water
instructions: Prepare the Fish: Clean and score the fish deeply on both sides. Rub the fish with turmeric powder and salt. Set aside.
Make the Paste: Mix the oil, ground ginger, ground garlic, chilli paste, tamarind water, and sugar to form a thick marinade.
Marinate and Prep for Grill: Rub the paste generously over both sides of the fish, making sure to push it into the scores. Let it sit for 15 minutes.

Grill: Preheat the grill to medium-high heat. Place the banana leaf or foil on the grill rack and place the marinated fish on top. Grill for 7-10 minutes per side (depending on the thickness), basting occasionally with any remaining marinade.
Check Doneness: The fish is cooked when the flesh near the bone (if using a whole fish) is opaque and the exterior is nicely charred. Serve immediately, topped with fresh lime/calamansi juice.

recipes.name: Fried Carrot Cake (White Version)
ingredients: 500g Steamed Radish Cake (Chai Tow Kway), cut into small cubes
1 tbsp Preserved Radish (Chai Poh), rinsed and drained
Chilli Paste (Sambal), served on the side
instructions: Prep Ingredients: Ensure the steamed radish cake is cool and cubed. Rinse the preserved radish (*Chai Poh*). Beat the eggs and season with fish sauce and light soy sauce.
Fry the Cake: Heat the oil/lard in a wok over high heat. Add the chopped radish cake cubes and fry until the edges are crispy (about 5-7 minutes). Push the cakes to the side.
Sauté Aromatics: Add a little more oil to the center of the wok. Add the chopped garlic and preserved radish (*Chai Poh*). Stir-fry quickly until fragrant (about 1 minute).
Combine and Season: Mix the fried cake, garlic, and *Chai Poh* together. Toss to combine.

Add Egg: Pour the seasoned beaten eggs over the mixture. Let the egg set slightly before tossing vigorously to incorporate the egg, wrapping creamy clumps around the cake pieces. Add white pepper and bean sprouts, tossing for a final 30 seconds.
Serve: Serve immediately while piping hot with a side of chili sauce.

recipes.name: Tutu Kueh (Steamed Rice Flour Cakes)
ingredients: 1.5 cups Fine Rice Flour (Steamed and dried for lightness)
1/2 cup Gula Melaka (Palm Sugar), finely shaved or powder
1/2 cup Roasted Peanuts, ground (or Coconut, grated)
Small squares of Banana Leaf or Pandan Leaf
instructions: Prepare the Flour: Sieve the fine rice flour and mix with salt. Sprinkle the water over the flour and gently rub it in with your fingers until the mixture resembles fine, damp sand. (Do not knead; it should remain powdery and light).
Prepare the Molds: Place a small square of banana or pandan leaf at the base of each *Tutu Kueh* mold (small flower shape or round).

Fill the Molds: Gently spoon the damp rice flour mixture into the mold, filling it halfway. Create a small indentation in the center. Fill the indentation with a spoonful of *Gula Melaka* powder or ground peanut filling. Top carefully with more rice flour until the mold is full.
Steam: Place the filled molds onto the steamer rack. Steam over high heat for 8-10 minutes. The kueh is done when it is firm and slightly puffed.
Unmold and Serve: Gently turn out the hot kueh onto a plate, ensuring the leaf is on the bottom. Serve immediately while the rice cake is fluffy and the filling is soft and melted.

recipes.name: Teochew Porridge (Mui)
instructions: Cook the Porridge: Combine the rinsed rice, water/stock, and salt in a large pot. Bring the mixture to a rapid boil.

Simmer: Immediately reduce the heat to a very gentle simmer. Cook for 35-45 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent the rice from sticking to the bottom. Unlike Cantonese congee, Teochew Mui should still have discernible, separate rice grains floating in the soupy liquid.
Finish: Once the grains are soft and the liquid is cloudy but still thin, adjust the salt seasoning and remove from heat.

Serve: Serve the plain, thin porridge piping hot in individual bowls. It is traditionally eaten with small plates of various savory side dishes, allowing the eater to customize the flavor of each mouthful.

recipes.name: Bak Chang (Rice Dumpling)
ingredients: 1 kg Glutinous Rice, washed, soaked for 2 hours, and drained
250g Pork Belly, diced (marinated in 5-spice, soy sauce, sugar)
10 Dried Shiitake Mushrooms, soaked and sliced
2 tbsp Dark Soy Sauce (for coloring rice)
instructions: Prepare Ingredients: Soak bamboo leaves and glutinous rice. Marinate the pork belly. Drain the rice and toss it with dark soy sauce, light soy sauce, and a little five-spice powder.

Wrap the Dumplings (Difficult): Take two soaked bamboo leaves, overlapping them to form a cone shape. Fill the cone with a layer of the seasoned glutinous rice. Create a well and place the fillings inside (pork, salted egg yolk, mushrooms, chestnuts, mung beans).

Seal: Top the filling with more glutinous rice. Fold the bamboo leaves tightly over the rice to form a neat pyramid shape. Tie securely with kitchen twine, ensuring it is very tight so the dumpling doesn't unravel during boiling.

Cook: Place the wrapped dumplings in a large pot and cover completely with water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 3-4 hours, adding more boiling water as needed to keep the dumplings fully submerged.
Serve: Remove the dumplings, hang them to drain, and cool slightly. Peel off the leaves and serve warm.

recipes.name: Kueh Pie Tee
ingredients: 1 cup Rice Flour, 1/4 cup Plain Flour
1/2 tsp Salt (requires *Kueh Pie Tee* mold for frying)
instructions: Make the Filling: Sauté garlic and *Tau Cheo* (fermented soybean paste) in oil. Add the shredded jicama and carrots. Add shrimp stock, sugar, and salt. Cover and simmer gently for 45-60 minutes until the vegetables are very soft and the liquid is mostly reduced. Keep warm.

Make the Shells: Whisk the rice flour, plain flour, egg, water, and salt until a smooth, thin batter forms. Heat 3 inches of oil in a pot to $180^\circ	ext{C}$ ($350^\circ	ext{F}$). Place the *Kueh Pie Tee* mold in the hot oil to heat for 5 minutes.

Fry the Shells: Dip the hot mold into the batter (but not over the top edge). Plunge the mold back into the hot oil. The batter should cook instantly and slip off the mold as a crispy cup. Fry until golden. Remove and drain on paper towels. Reheat mold before dipping again.
Assemble: Spoon the warm jicama filling into the crispy cups. Top with a cooked small prawn, a sprinkle of chopped coriander, and a dab of chilli sauce. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Peranakan Chap Chye (Mixed Vegetables)
ingredients: 5 pieces Dried Fungus (Black Wood Ear), soaked and sliced
200g Glass Noodles (Tang Hoon), soaked and cut
50g Dried Lily Flowers (Kam Cham), soaked and knotted
2 tbsp Tau Cheo (Fermented Soybean Paste), mashed
instructions: Prepare Vegetables: Shred the cabbage and jicama. Soak and prepare the dried fungus and lily flowers. Slice the pork belly (if using).
Sauté Aromatics: Heat oil in a large pot or wok. Add the sliced pork belly (if using) and cook until fat is rendered. Add the mashed *Tau Cheo* (fermented soybean paste) and stir-fry until fragrant.
Braise Vegetables: Add the shredded jicama and cabbage to the pot. Stir-fry for 3-5 minutes until slightly wilted. Add the chicken stock, soy sauce, and sugar.

Simmer: Add the dried fungus and lily flowers. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 20-30 minutes, or until the vegetables are very soft and tender. This dish relies on slow cooking until soft.
Finish with Noodles: Add the soaked glass noodles during the last 5 minutes of cooking. Stir until the noodles are soft and the gravy is mostly absorbed. Season to taste and serve hot with rice.

recipes.name: Chendol Durian
ingredients: 4 tbsp Gula Melaka Syrup (Palm Sugar Syrup)
1 cup Durian Pulp (D24, Musang King, or equivalent), pureed or whole pieces
instructions: Prepare the Components: Ensure the *Gula Melaka* syrup and thick coconut milk are chilled. Ensure the *Cendol* jellies are drained and the red beans are cooked and sweetened. Have the durian pulp ready.
Mound the Ice: Fill a serving bowl generously with finely shaved ice, creating a dome shape.
Layer the Base: Add the *Cendol* jellies and red beans around the base of the ice mound.
Add Durian: Place a generous scoop of the durian pulp (or pureed durian) directly on top of the shaved ice mound.
Drizzle and Serve: Pour the chilled coconut milk and *Gula Melaka* syrup liberally over the entire dessert, ensuring the durian and ice are coated. Serve immediately with a long spoon.

recipes.name: Tau Kwa Pau
ingredients: 100g Crispy Fried Yam or Taro, diced (optional)
instructions: Make the Stuffing: Slice the hard-boiled eggs and cube the fish cake and fried yam/taro. Gently mix these ingredients with the chopped coriander/spring onion.
Prepare the *Tau Kwa*: Cut each large *Tau Kwa* puff halfway open, creating a pocket. Gently scoop out a small amount of the interior soft tofu to make room for the stuffing.
Stuff the *Tau Kwa*: Carefully fill each *Tau Kwa* pocket generously with the mixed stuffing ingredients. Arrange them in a serving dish.

Make the Sauce: Combine the dark soy sauce, water, sugar, and five-spice powder in a small saucepan. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 5 minutes until the sauce slightly thickens to a glaze.
Serve: Drizzle the warm, savory-sweet dark sauce glaze generously over the stuffed *Tau Kwa* puffs. Serve immediately with a side of sweet chilli sauce for dipping.

recipes.name: Bubur Cha Cha
ingredients: 1 cup Assorted Sweet Potato (orange, purple, yellow), cubed
instructions: Cook Starchy Ingredients: Boil the cubed sweet potato and yam separately until they are just tender (do not overcook). Drain and set aside. Boil the sago pearls until translucent, then rinse with cold water and set aside.
Prepare the Broth: In a large pot, combine the thin coconut milk, sugar, salt, and knotted pandan leaves. Bring to a gentle simmer, stirring constantly until the sugar dissolves.
Combine and Simmer: Add the cooked sweet potatoes, yam, and Nyonya jellies to the simmering coconut milk. Simmer gently for 5 minutes.

Finish: Pour in the thick coconut milk. Stir gently and heat until the mixture is hot, but **do not boil vigorously** after adding the thick coconut milk. Adjust sweetness and salt to taste. Remove the pandan leaves.
Serve: Stir in the cooked sago pearls. Serve warm or chilled in bowls.
